paragraphs.context: Following the independence and truce war in July 1921, representatives of the British Government and Irish contract delegates under Arthur Griffith, Robert Barton and Michael Collins negotiated an Anglo-Ireland agreement in London from 11 October to 6 December 1921. Irish delegates set up headquarters in Hans Place, Knightsbridge, and here, on 5 December, it was decided to recommend an agreement to Dáil Éireann. The second Dáil Éireann ratified the agreement sparsely. In accordance with the agreement, the whole island of Ireland became a sovereign self-governing ruler on 6 December 1922, called the Irish Free State. According to the Constitution of the Irish Free State, the Parliament of Northern Ireland had the opportunity to leave the Irish Free State one month later and return to the United Kingdom. During the interim period, the powers of the Irish Free State Parliament and the Irish Free State Executive Council did not extend to Northern Ireland. Northern Ireland exercised its Treaty right to leave the new Dominion and returned to the United Kingdom on 8 December 1922. It did so by keeping the king's request that 'the powers of parliament and government of the free State of Ireland no longer extend to Northern Ireland'. The Irish Free State was a constitutional monarchy that divided the monarchy with the British and other British masters of the Commonwealth. There was a governor-in-chief, a two-chamber parliament, a government called the "Technical Council" and a prime minister called the President-in-Office of the Executive Council.

The industrial tradition of the Czech Republic dates back to the 19th century, when the states of the Bohemian Crown were the economic and industrial heartland of the Austrian Empire and later Austria-Hungary. The Czech countries produced the majority of all industrial products in the country, some of which were almost monopolistic. The Chekkoslovak crown was introduced in April 1919. It became one of the most stable currencies in Europe when it was introduced in relation to the Austrian-Hungary currency 1:1. The first republic became one of the ten most developed countries in the world. The economic consequences of the Munich Treaty and the post-Multi-München occupation were disastrous. After the economy was occupied and forced into German economic interests, the value of the crown was officially 1:10, although the informal exchange rate was 1-6-7 and the Germans immediately started buying Czech products in large quantities. In line with Stalin's policy of interdependency development, all the economies of the socialist countries were closely linked to the Soviet economy. Czechoslovakia was the wealthiest country in the Eastern bloc, but it was still lagging behind the rest of the developed world. After the break-up of the Communist economic union in 1991, Czech manufacturers lost their traditional markets among the former Communist countries of the East. Today, this legacy is both a resource and a burden. The Czech Republic has a well-trained population and a well-developed infrastructure.

paragraphs.context: In the Moreen war, the Republic of Venice surrounded Sinji in October 1684 and then again in March-April 1685, but both times without success. In 1685, Venetian armies were assisted by the local militia of the Republic of Poljica, who rebelled against the nominal Susation of Ottomans, which had existed since 1513. In their attempt to avenge Poljica in June 1685, the Ottomans attacked Zadvarje and in July 1686 attacked Dolac and Srijane, but they were pushed back and suffered great losses. With the help of the local Poljica population and the Morlachis, Sinji’s fortress finally fell into the hands of the Venetian army on September 30, 1686. The siege of Herceg Novi began on September 1, 1687 and ended with the Venetian victory on September 30. Knin was taken after the siege of 12 days on September 11, 1688. The capture of Knin fortresses meant the end of a successful Venetian campaign to expand their territory in the interior of Dalmatia, and it also defined a large part of the current final border between Dalmatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Ottomans would surround Sinji again in the Second Morean War, but they would be repugnant. Venice took Vrgorac on November 26, 1690, which opened the way for Imotsky and Mostar. In 1694 they succeeded in occupying the northern regions of the Ragusa Republic, namely Čitluk, Abela, Zažablje, Trebinje, Popovo, Klobuk and Metković. paragraphs.context: The Spanish took part in a strategy to concentrate indigenous people on newly established colonial cities, the Reduccions. New settlements were resisted by indigenous peoples fleeing to difficult areas such as the forest or joining neighbouring Maya groups that had not yet submitted to the Spaniards. Those who were left behind in the Reduccions were often infected with infectious diseases. An example of the impact of this strategy on the population is the province of Acalan, which has the southern Campeche and the eastern Tabasco region. When Hernán Cortés passed through Acalan in 1525, he estimated the population to be at least 10,000. In 1553 the population was about 4,000. In 1557, the mob was transferred by force to Tixchel on the Gulf Coast to make the Spanish authorities more accessible. In 1561, the Spaniards recorded only 250 persons paying tribute to Tixchel, likely having a population of about 1,100. This suggests a 90% reduction in the population over a 36-year period. Some of the inhabitants had fled from Tixchel to the forest, while others had fallen into the diseases of Reducción in Spain, malnutrition and inadequate housing. The Reduccions on the coast were nice for the Spanish administration, but they were vulnerable to attacks by pirates. In the case of Tixchel, attacks by pirates and infectious European diseases led to the destruction of the city of Reducción and the extinction of Campechen Chontal Maya. The Jacobite troops quickly defeated the Protestant inhabitants of Bandon in Cork County. By November 1688 only the city on the wall of Derry had a Protestant garrison. The Jacobite army, consisting of some 1200 men, mostly "Punahank", was slowly organized under the direction of Earl Aleksandr MacDonnell of Antrim 3. When they arrived on December 7, 1688, the gates were closed against them, and the siege of Derry began. Although Jacobites seemed to have great advantages in the Irish forces, the troops raised by Tyrconnell were mainly hastily equipped country bands, most of which were poorly armed and trained. About five kilometers west of Warsaw and St. Petersburg’s railway line was based on a military situation on the ground and not on ethnic composition. The Poles and the Lithuanians were not satisfied with the line. The Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs rejected this line because it would require Polish troops to retreat as far as 35 kilometres away. The Lithuanians protested when they left Vilnius and Hrodna to control Poland. After the German volunteers left Lithuania and the Lithuanian troops concentrated on fighting the Russians in northern Lithuania, Poland attacked the 100 km wide front and moved 20-30 km further into the Lithuanian territory. On 18 July, Ferdinand Foch proposed a second line known as Foch Line. It was adopted by Entente on 26 July. The Lithuanians were not informed of the new policy until 3 August. Two major changes were made to the Polish population: the Suwałki region was assigned to Poland and the whole line was transferred about seven kilometres west. Both Poles and Lithuanians are protesting the line again because it would require them to withdraw their armies from the areas of Vilnius and Suwałk. paragraphs.context: As in most civil wars, the Internesian conflict left a bitter legacy that continues to affect Irish policy to this day. The two largest political parties in the Republic through most of their history were Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael, descendants of the anti- and anti-treaty forces of 1922. Until the 1970s, almost all major Irish politicians were veterans of the civil war, which poisoned the relationship between the two largest Irish parties. The veterans of the Civil War include the Republicans Éamon de Valera, Frank Aiken, Todd Andrews and Seán Lemass, and the Free State supporters W. T. Cosgrave, Richard Mulcahy and Kevin O'Higgins. Moreover, many of these men’s sons and daughters became politicians, meaning that the personal injuries of the civil war were experienced within three generations. In the 1930s, when Fianna Fáil came to power for the first time, it seemed possible for a moment that civil war could erupt again between the IRA and the blue shirts of the Free State. Fortunately, this crisis was combated and, by the 1950s, violence was no longer prominent in the policy of the Republic of Ireland. However, the IRA, which was decoupled from the IRA, continued to exist. It was not until 1948 that the IRA gave up military attacks against the Irish South State troops when it became the Republic of Ireland. After that, the organisation was primarily committed to the end of the British regime in Northern Ireland. The IRA Army Council continues to claim to be the legal temporary government of the Republic of Ireland, declared in 1918 and repealed by an Anglo-Irish agreement in 1921.

paragraphs.context: The revolution of October 5, 1910, was the overthrow of the centuries - old Portuguese monarchy and its replacement by the Portuguese Republic. It was the result of the coup d'état organised by the Portuguese Republican Party. By 1910 the Kingdom of Portugal was in a deep crisis: British pressure on the Portuguese colonies, the cost of the royal family, the murder of the king and his heir in 1908, the change of religious and social views, the instability of two political parties, the dictatorship of João Franco and the apparent inability of the regime to adapt to modern times led to widespread resentment against the monarchy. The republican supporters, especially the Republican Party, found ways to take advantage of the situation. The Republican Party presented itself as the only one with a programme that could return to its lost position and put Portugal on the road to development. The soldiers were reluctant to fight almost 2,000 soldiers and sailors who rebelled on October 3-4, 1910. The republic was declared at 9 a.m. on the next day’s balcony of Paços do Concelho in Lisbon. After the revolution, the temporary government led by Teófilo Braga guided the country’s destiny until the Constitution was adopted in 1911, marking the beginning of the first republic. With the establishment of the Republic, the national anthem and the flag changed, among other things. The revolution produced some civil and religious freedoms, although there was no progress in the rights of women and workers, unlike in other European countries.

The Dutch fortresses consisted of two fortifications along the bay: the first and most important fort was a multiwalled Fort Zeeland, located at the mouth of the bay, while the second was a smaller Fort Provint, a masonry administration office. paragraphs.context: The economic change in the country was far from complete. Political and economic crises in 1997 shattered the image of the Czech Republic as one of the most stable and prosperous Communist states. The delay in restructuring companies and the failure of well-functioning capital markets were important factors in the Czech economy, which culminated in the currency crisis in May. The former currency was put into a floating system when investors sold their jewelry faster than the government could buy them. This followed the global trend to abandon developing countries that year. Investors were also concerned that the economic change in the Republic was far from complete. Another complicating factor was the current account deficit, which was close to 8% of GDP. In the wake of the crisis, two savings packages were introduced later in the spring, reducing government expenditure by 2.5% of GDP. The growth fell to 0.3% in 1997, -2.3% in 1998 and -0.5% in 1999. The Government set up a restructuring agency in 1999 and launched a recovery programme to encourage business sales to foreign companies. The main priorities were the approximation of legislation to EU standards, the reorganisation of businesses and the privatisation of banks and businesses.
